>From: "Chad Bohannan" <chad@...>
>Reply-To: neat@yahoogroups.com
>To: <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Using NEAT to Mimic Facial Expressions
>Date: Thu, 10 Jun 2004 13:00:38 -0700
>
>ooooo! if you perl/java guys could make a framework where we could take
>advantage of the amazing human processing power that internet makes
>available, that could prove to be the most powerfull fitness function
>ever. Each test would obviously be slower, but it could be as parrellel
>as the number of users, and the accuracy of the results would be very
>high, statisticly speaking. That's a great idea.

Well, actually, now that you mention it...After I get my image enlargement 
experiment running, I've got another experiment in mind that is based on 
human generated data.  It's not QUITE the same thing, but close...

I currently have a database of pictures I've taken.  I have a web page where 
it shows me two pictures side-by-side.  I click on the one I like better.  I 
use that data to build a ranking so that the best pictures appear first in 
the list.  It works well.

I'd like to extract a bunch of 'characteristics' from each image, and use 
those as inputs into a neural network, and use that data as the training 
data.  Then, when I add a bunch of new pictures to the database, I can let 
the network pre-classify their relationship to the others.  If the network 
doesn't have a CLEAR preference, it passes on the comparison.  When it is 
done, the best pictures automatically end up near the top, the dogs 
automatically fall to the bottom.
